S4.T1.caption: Table 1: The default configuration of our work
S4.T1.table:
Parameter Default value
Learning rate (η𝜂\eta)
0.010.010.01(CIFAR-101010)
0.10.10.1 (others)
Batch size (B𝐵B) 646464
Number of clients (m𝑚m) 101010
Number of communication rounds (T𝑇T) 100100100
Number of local epochs (E𝐸E) 101010
Concentration parameter (β𝛽\beta) 0.50.50.5
references:
We conduct experiments over three standard datasets: CIFAR-10 (60,000 images with 10 classes), CIFAR-100 (60,000 images with 100 classes), and Tiny-ImageNet (100,000 images with 200 classes). For a fair comparison, we use the same modules in the local network for all approaches. As in the previous work (Li, He, and Song 2021), we use a simple CNN model as the base encoder for CIFAR-101010 and use ResNet-50 (He et al. 2016) as the base encoder for CIFAR-100 and Tiny-ImageNet. Note that the simple CNN model has two 5×5555\times 5 convolution layers followed by 2×2222\times 2 max pooling and two fully connected layers with ReLU activation.
For all datasets, the projection head consists of a 2-layer MLP with an output size of 256, and the output layer is just a single linear layer. We use Dirichlet distribution to generate the non-IID data distribution as previous studies (Wang et al. 2020a; Yurochkin et al. 2019). Specifically, we draw pk∼D​i​r​N​(β)similar-tosuperscript𝑝𝑘𝐷𝑖𝑟𝑁𝛽p^{k}\sim DirN(\beta) from a Dirichlet distribution and allocate a piksubscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑘𝑖p^{k}_{i} proportion of the instances of class k𝑘k to client Cisubscript𝐶𝑖C_{i}, where β𝛽\beta is a concentration parameter controlling the identicalness among clients.
Table 1 lists the default configuration of our work.

FedProc 70.7%±0.3%plus-or-minuspercent70.7percent0.3\mathbf{70.7\%\pm 0.3\%} 74.6%±0.1%plus-or-minuspercent74.6percent0.1\mathbf{74.6\%\pm 0.1\%} 35.4%±0.1%plus-or-minuspercent35.4percent0.1\mathbf{35.4\%\pm 0.1\%}
references:
Table 2 lists the top-111 test accuracy of all methods. SOLO shows the worst result among all methods, which demonstrates the advantages of federated learning. FedAvg is the first FL framework that uses cross-entropy loss to train the local network, which can be regarded as a baseline for FL. The other FL framework including SCAFFOLD, FedProx, and MOON are designed to address the non-IID data issue. Since FedAvg does not make any optimization for the non-IID setting, the accuracy of FedAvg is relatively low among all FL algorithms. Furthermore, SCAFFOLD is proposed to improve the accuracy on the CIFAR-10, but it has much worse results on CIFAR-100 and Tiny-ImageNet than FedAvg. For FedProx, its accuracy is very close to that of FedAvg. It is because that FedProx makes only minor modifications on the FedAvg by using re-parameterization techniques. MOON presents a model contrastive federated learning, which compares the representations learned by different models. This approach outperforms FedAvg by 1.3%∼3%similar-topercent1.3percent31.3\%\sim 3\% accuracy on the different datasets. As for our method (FedProc), we can observe that its accuracy results are always better than those of other methods for all datasets. Specifically, our method outperforms MOON by 1.6%∼7.9%similar-topercent1.6percent7.91.6\%\sim 7.9\% on the different datasets. It is indicated that our method (prototypical contrastive federated learning) can effectively correct the local training.
Next, we explore the impact of different parameters on accuracy.

references:
To assess the impact of the data heterogeneity on the accuracy, we ran the experiments on heterogeneous data by varying the concentration parameter β𝛽\beta of the Dirichlet distribution on the CIFAR100 dataset. A smaller β𝛽\beta indicates a more skewed data distribution. The results in Table 3 shows that FedProc consistently achieves the best accuracy with all levels of imbalance. Specifically, FedProc outperforms MOON by 7.6%percent7.67.6\% accuracy when β=5𝛽5\beta=5.
When the data distributions are highly heterogeneous (β=0.5,0.1𝛽0.50.1\beta=0.5,0.1), FedProc still outperformed MOON by 7.1%percent7.17.1\% and 4.9%percent4.94.9\% accuracy, respectively. This result verifies our motivations, since the advantage of FedProc benefits from the introduction of class prototypes, which serve as global knowledge to correct the local training. In contrast, other methods do not make full use of the underlying knowledge, such as the global class-prototypes.

S4.T4.caption: Table 4: The top-1 accuracy with different kinds of loss of local objective.
S4.T4.table:
Method CIFAR-10 CIFAR-100 Tiny-ImageNet
Two-stage FL 65.10%percent65.1065.10\% 67.50%percent67.5067.50\% 24.70%percent24.7024.70\%
FedProc(α𝛼\alpha= 0.5) 66.30%percent66.3066.30\% 68.90%percent68.9068.90\% 30.20%percent30.2030.20\%
FedProc 70.70%percent70.70\mathbf{70.70\%} 74.60%percent74.60\mathbf{74.60\%} 35.40%percent35.40\mathbf{35.40\%}
references: In this work, we use the coefficient α𝛼\alpha to adjust the weights of the feature learning and classifier learning during the local training. To demonstrate the superiority of our method, we design a two-stage federated learning inspired by two-stage work (Khosla et al. 2020). This method trains the features by ℓg​p​csubscriptℓ𝑔𝑝𝑐\ell_{gpc} loss in the first stage and then fixes the features to train classifiers in the second stage. As shown in Table 4, the accuracy of our method is evidently higher than that of the two-stage training method. It is because that the training with two stages breaks the compatibility between feature learning and classifier learning. To validate the efficacy of the setting method of α𝛼\alpha, we re-run FedProc when fixing α=0.5𝛼0.5\alpha=0.5. Obviously, the results in this setting are worse than ours. When α=1−tT𝛼1𝑡𝑇\alpha=1-\frac{t}{T}, FedProc learns better representations in the early stages of the training, making it have the greater classification capacity in the later stages.

S4.T5.caption: Table 5: The average training time per round.
S4.T5.table:
Method CIFAR-10 CIFAR-100 Tiny-ImageNet
FedAvg 8min34s 24min36s 104min11s
SCAFFOLD 8min43s 27min55s 181min56s
FedProx 8min52s 27min28s 117min7s
MOON 9min6s 45min5s 186min10s
FedProc 11min57s 27min41s 111min12s
references:
To make a fair comparison, we measure the computation cost of all the above methods under the same machines. Table 5 shows the average training time per round. We can observe that the average training time of FedAvg is the lowest of all. The reason is, FedProx, MOON, and FedProc introduce additional loss items based on FedAvg, and SCAFFOLD introduces additional control variables for the server and clients. We also find that the average training time of FedProc on CIFAR-101010 and CIFAR-100100100 is nearly the same as most of the methods (e.g., SCAFFOLD and FedProx).
As a highlight, FedProc on Tiny-ImageNet is superior to other methods (except FedAvg). We can conclude that FedProc has more advantages in the computation cost as the volume of data and the scale of local networks increases.

references:
In order to demonstrate the scalability of FedProc, we ran the experiments on CIFAR-100 with a large number of clients. As in the previous work (Li, He, and Song 2021), the number of clients (m𝑚m) is set to 505050 (with sampling rate γ=1𝛾1\gamma=1) and 100100100 (with sampling rate γ=0.2𝛾0.2\gamma=0.2). Note that γ=0.2𝛾0.2\gamma=0.2 means that 202020 clients out of 100100100 clients are randomly selected to participate in the training in each round (refer to FedAvg (McMahan et al. 2017) for client sampling technology).
The results in Table 6 and Figure 6 demonstrate the excellent scalability of FedProc, whose accuracy is far higher than those of the other methods. In particular, our method outperforms MOON by 9.3%percent9.39.3\% accuracy when the number of rounds T=200𝑇200T=200 and the number of clients m=50𝑚50m=50.
The excellent scalability of FedProc is due to the introduction of prototypical contrastive learning. This improvement makes local objectives of each client consistent with the global optima, such that the performance of FedProc will not be affected as the number of clients increases.
